questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to the OPD with reading difficulty in his left eye 6 weeks after an injury to his right eye with a log of wood the most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sympathetic ophthalmitis It is a rare bilateral granulomatous panuveitis that is known to occur following penetrating ocular trauma usually associated with the incarceration of uveal tissue in the wound The injured eye is known as the exciting eye The fellow eye which also develops uveitis is known as sympathizing eye Injury in one eye can lead to loss of vision in the other eye along with it.

Highyeild:

Sympathetic ophthalmia Etiology Predisposing factors: l. It almost always follows a penetrating injury . Wounds in the ciliary region ( the so-called dangerous zone) are more prone to it. Wounds with the incarceration of the iris, ciliary body, or lens capsule are more vulnerable. It is more common in children than in adults. It does not occur when actual suppuration develops in the injured eye. Pathogenesis : Various theories have been put forward. The most accepted one is an allergic theory, which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye. Pathology It is characteristic of granulomatous uveitis, e. there is • Nodular aggregation of lymphocytes, plasma cells, epithelioid cells, and giant cells scattered throughout the uveal tract. • Dalen-Fuchs' nodules are formed due to the proliferation of the pigment epithelium (of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid) associated with invasion by the lymphocytes and epithelioid cells . • Sympathetic perivasculitis . The retina shows perivascular cellular infiltration. Clinical features Exciting (injured) eye. It shows clinical features of persistent low-grade plastic uveitis, which include ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. Keratic precipitates may be present at the back of the cornea ( dangerous sign ). Sympathizing (sound) eye. It is usually involved after 4-8 weeks of injury in the other eye . The earliest reported case is after 9 days of injury . Sympathetic ophthalmitis, almost always, manifests as acute plastic iridocyclitis . Rarely it may manifest as neuro retinitis or choroiditis. Clinical features of iridocyclitis in the sympathetic eye can be divided into two stages : Prodromal stage. Sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects (due to weakening of accommodation) are the earliest symptoms. In this stage, the first sign may be the presence of retrolental flare and cells or the presence of a few keratic precipitates (KPs) on the back of the cornea. Other signs include mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and disc edema which is seen occasionally. Fully-developed stage . It is clinically characterized by typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis

questions.text: Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada Syndrome includes which clinical feature set?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypopigmentation, Uveitis, Neuropathy, Tinnitus. Vogt-Koyanagi syndrome It is an idiopathic multisystem disorder that includes cutaneous, neurological, and ocular lesions. The disease is comparatively more common in Japanese who are usually positive for HLA-DR4 and DWl 5.

Highyeild:

VKH syndrome is an idiopathic, multisystemic autoimmune disease featuring inflammation of melanocytes containing tissues affecting the uvea, ear, skin, and meninges Ocular signs : B/L granulomatous panuveitis Posterior uveitis Diffuse choroiditis Exudative retinal detachment Exudative retinal detachment Sunset glow fundus due to diffuse retinal pigment epithelium atrophy Sugiura sign - perilimbal vitiligo Dahlen Fuch nodules Subretinal fibrosis, cataracts, glaucoma Anterior uveitis Systemic features : Meningismus Tinnitus Cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis Alopecia poliosis Vitiligo Complications include cataracts, glaucoma, and CNV membrane. Treatments of uveitis: Corticosteroids administered topically, periocular, and systemically (in high doses) constitute the mainstay of treatment. Immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate, azathioprine, and cyclosporine should be considered for resistant and recurrent cases

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Hypopigmentation, Uveitis, heterochromia, Poliosis: heterochromia not seen with VKH syndrome Option: C. Hypopigmentation, Uveitis, Neuropathy, Aphthous Ulcer: Aphthous Ulcer not seen with VKH syndrome Option: D. Hypopigmentation, Vitritis, Vitreous hemorrhage, Tinnitus: Vitreous haemorrhage not seen with VKH syndrome

Extraedge:

For many years, the treatment for VKH was intravenous pulse corticosteroid therapy. Subtenon injection of triamcinolone is highly effective in leading to resolution without recurrence of ocular symptoms monotherapy sub-tenon injection of steroids is ideal, specifically for patients already on systemic Immunomodulatory therapy (IMT) or who have minimal systemic symptoms of their disease Systemic Immunomodulatory therapy (IMT) : Cyclosporine has shown improved efficacy in cases of chronic uveitis VKH. Methotrexate has shown good efficacy in studies combining methotrexate with fluocinolone intravitreal implants, while infliximab shows promise in pediatric populations. Adalimumab has most recently been studied in recalcitrant cases of patients with corticosteroid-related complications and challenging pediatric cases.(source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK574571/ )

questions.text: One 45 years old female presented in your ophthalmology emergency for sudden onset of blurring of vision in two eyes. She also experiences a ringing sensation in his ears with a sudden internal spinning sensation a few days back. Findings are: What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome VOGT-KOYANAGI-HARADA (VKH) SYNDROME It is an idiopathic multisystem disorder that includes cutaneous, neurological , and ocular lesions . The disease is comparatively more common in Japanese who are usually positive for HLA-DR4 and DW15. Clinical features 1. Cutaneous lesions include alopecia, poliosis , and vitiligo. 2. Neurological lesions are in the form of meningism, encephalopathy, tinnitus, vertigo , and deafness. 3. Ocular features are bilateral chronic granulomatous anterior uveitis, posterior uveitis, and exudative retinal detachment. Complications include cataracts, glaucoma, and CNV membrane. Treatments of uveitis: Corticosteroids administered topically, periocular, and systemically (in high doses) constitute the mainstay of treatment. Immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate, azathioprine, and cyclosporine should be considered for resistant and recurrent cases

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Behcet’s Syndrome - a rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous signs and symptoms that can seem unrelated at first. They can include mouth sores, eye inflammation, skin rashes and lesions, and genital sores. Option: B. Sarcoidosis - Sarcoidosis is a disease characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells (granulomas) in any part of your body — most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes. But it can also affect the eyes, skin, heart, and other organs. Option: C. Toxoplasmosis - a disease that results from infection with the Toxoplasma gondii parasite, one of the world's most common parasites. Infection usually occurs by eating undercooked contaminated meat, exposure to infected cat feces, or mother-to-child transmission during pregnancy.

questions.correct_answer: D. A congested eye with positive for HLA-BW54
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A congested eye with positive for HLA-BW54 Posner-Schlossman syndrome is characterized by White-eye (no congestion ).

Highyeild:

GLAUCOMATOCYCLITIC CRISIS Clinical features Posner Schlossman syndrome is characterized by: Recurrent unilateral attacks of the acute rise of intraocular pressure (40-50 mm of Hg) without shallowing of anterior chamber associated with, Fine KPs at the back of the cornea, without any posterior synechiae, Epithelial edema of the cornea, Dilated pupil, White-eye (no congestion ), and The disease typically affects young adults, 40% of whom are positive for HLA-BW54. Treatment • Antiglaucoma drugs, to lower intraocular pressure, along with • Topical steroids, a short course.

questions.text: Which is the most common ocular finding in myasthenia gravis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ptosis Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disease in which antibodies destroy neuromuscular connections resulting in muscle weakness and fatigability. MG affects voluntary muscles of the body, but the muscles and motor nerves are intact. Smaller muscles tend to be affected first, larger muscles become affected as the disease progresses. Ocular MG affects only the ocular muscles. Systemic MG affects the ocular muscles (often the presenting sign) and other voluntary muscles. Approximately 85% of patients presenting with only ocular signs and symptoms of MG will develop systemic MG within 2 years of presentation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father for an annual health maintenance examination. His father notes that he has several pigmented areas on his skin and a few fleshy bumps. He has also had some blurred vision in his left eye. He has no history of serious medical illness. He lives at home with both parents and is up-to-date on all his immunizations. His father has similar skin findings. His mother has epilepsy and glaucoma. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity testing shows 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows pigmented iris nodules. Examination of his skin shows eight brownish macules and numerous soft, non-tender, pedunculated lesions on the back, chest, and abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI of the Brain This child has pigmented iris nodules (Lisch nodules) and multiple pigmented macules (cafe-au-lait spots). These findings fulfill the diagnostic criteria for neurofibromatosis type I . Patients with NF1 are at increased risk of developing benign and malignant nervous system tumors, especially optic gliomas. Although optic gliomas are usually asymptomatic, patients may develop visual abnormalities, including proptosis, decreased color vision, and/or decreased visual acuity, as seen in this patient. All patients with NF1 and visual symptoms should undergo MRI with contrast for further evaluation.

Highyeild:

NEUROFIBROMATOSIS (VON RECKLINGHAUSEN'S DISEASE) It is characterized by multiple tumours in the skin, nervous system, and other organs . Cutaneous manifestations are very characteristic and vary from cafe-au-lait spots to neurofibroma . Ocular manifestations include neurofibromas of the lids and orbit, glioma of the optic nerve, and congenital glaucoma.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . CT scan is commonly used in the emergency setting to rapidly evaluate for trauma, space-occupying lesions, hydrocephalus, and intracranial bleeding. While patients with NF1 are at increased risk of developing CNS tumors, a CT scan is not the best study for evaluating his visual deficits. Option: C . Gonioscopy involves the placement of a lens (gonioscope) on the cornea to visualize the anterior chamber and chamber angle. It is considered the gold standard for the diagnosis of glaucoma. Early glaucoma is common in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome but is uncommon in patients with NF1. Option: D. EEG records electrical activity in the brain and is used to diagnose or screen for seizure activity. While patients with NF1 are at increased risk of developing CNS tumors, which could cause seizure activity, this patient has no reported history of seizures and there is no indication to screen for seizures in NF1.
